Purpose - To provide a guide to the tasks and behaviours required of a person when conducting a safety observation.

Scope - 1. If you are a team leader, ensure you are familiar with this guide before attempting to conduct a safety observation. 2. If you are an assessor or are auditing a person conducting a safety observation, then use this checklist as an assessment / auditing instrument.
Gather area-specific data before starting (review past audits; Hazard Register; use an SOP as reference; specific hazards or conditions today).
Check the area is safe – observe from a safe position first before entering
TASK OBSERVED - KEY ISSUES - Is it a killer?
In the first 30 seconds after entering the area check for: 1. Evaporative behaviour (How people are behaving). 2. The hazards
If you observe an unsafe act or condition: (IMMEDIATE DANGER) 1. Stop the work until it is made safe. Never walk past or ‘look the other way’. Inform the supervisor later, if he is not present.

If you observe a behaviour or situation that doesn’t ‘feel’ right: 1. When it is safe to gain the person’s attention, check the behaviour/situation. 2. If the person’s answer again doesn’t feel right, tell the person you will check with the area owner, and do so immediately if necessary
ENGAGEMENT WITH THE EMPLOYEE - Greet / introduce / clarify the purpose of the observation 1. Always praise the positive behaviour observed - FIRST

INVOLVE THE PERSON - PROMPTS 1. What are the hazards of the task? 2. Is this how you would normally do the task 3. Why do you do it that way? 4. Are you following the operating procedure? (pre-check etc) 5. Are there other ways to do the task? 6. What are the emergency stop procedures? 7. What has gone wrong/ nearly gone wrong before? 8. When and what was the last incident in this area? 9. How can the task be made safer?
At risk behaviour is discussed (if applicable):
Employee committed to adopt safe behaviour: (plan)
Discuss the plan with the operator’s supervisor / manager.
